text: for example look at profiles of Blair Hull, Jeff Yass and Aaron Brown (i posted a thing about him the other day). _unsurprisingly_ there are fairly deep connections between poker, blackjack, sports betting and trading. once normalised for specifics, the high level principals of expectation maximisation remain the same across domains. that is not to say that everything is the same. “We think in generalities, but we live in detail”

text: I'm not any kind of expert in financial markets, but it strikes me that the fundamental difference between those and gambling is that in most financials trading you're buying and selling assets that have a positive expectancy such as businesses, or else providing services to them or trading derivatives which in themselves have some utility even if it's a long way down the chain. Gambling markets by contrast are negative expectancy on net because value is sucked out by the platform. In the simplest case you can buy shares at random and expect a profit, if you gamble at random you lose.  It's interesting to me that many financials traders seem to enjoy using gambling terminology about their work, talking about 'bets' when they've actually bought something - perhaps because it makes it sound exciting, whereas a lot of gamblers use financial terminology about gambling to make it sound sensible.

elements.text: I'm not any kind of expert in financial markets, but it strikes me that the fundamental difference between those and gambling is that in most financials trading you're buying and selling assets that have a positive expectancy such as businesses, or else providing services to them or trading derivatives which in themselves have some utility even if it's a long way down the chain. Gambling markets by contrast are negative expectancy on net because value is sucked out by the platform. In the simplest case you can buy shares at random and expect a profit, if you gamble at random you lose.  It's interesting to me that many financials traders seem to enjoy using gambling terminology about their work, talking about 'bets' when they've actually bought something - perhaps because it makes it sound exciting, whereas a lot of gamblers use financial terminology about gambling to make it sound sensible.

text: I think that's mostly it... I think it helps to just remember that in both markets people have different goals. Investing in stocks may be generally +ve EV, but if that was the end of the story then market makers would lose money. I think the goal of most in gambling market is to get a bet on and have some fun. In the stock market these participants exist too, it's just that the proportion of folk looking for speculative fun from a bet is higher in betting markets. If the point is that gambling achieves very little economic benefit, then I whole-heartedly agree.

elements.text: I think that's mostly it... I think it helps to just remember that in both markets people have different goals. In the stock market these participants exist too, it's just that the proportion of folk looking for speculative fun from a bet is higher in betting markets. If the point is that gambling achieves very little economic benefit, then I whole-heartedly agree.

text: There is also a difference if you model on the results of the sports rather than market movements. There is no equivalent in financial trading, and there is no equivalence to the stability of returns with a good model based on sporting results. I know of two very large organisations in sports betting and financial trading. The sports betting organisation checks returns every few weeks, The financial trading organisation checks positions every few hours
